text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single-column text block below a full-width rectangular miniature; the image spans the top third of the page, framed by a painted architectural border; a large ornamental initial begins the text directly beneath the miniature; wide blank margins surround the composition.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata with uniform stroke weight, regular spacing, frequent use of common medieval abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for halos, the idol’s altar and decorative frame, signifying divine and cultic importance. Ultramarine is used for the martyr’s cloak and floor pattern to draw focus. Vermilion and green alternate on garments and architectural elements to balance warm and cool tones. Figures are modeled by layering pigments with white highlights and slight hatching for volume. The initial and border feature gold ground with white vine scrolls, combining metallic brilliance with fine detail. Pigments remain vibrant with minimal oxidation of lead white.

content_theme.scene_description: The single narrative scene is set within a unified miniature framed by red and white columns and a central Gothic arch. On the left, inside an imperial hall with decorated floor tiles, a haloed martyr stands in prayer before a pagan idol placed on an elevated altar. He wears an ultramarine cloak lined in green over a red tunic, his arms uplifted. Behind him, five soldiers and a crowned figure in a gold-trimmed red cloak gesture insistently toward the idol. On the right, set against rolling green hills and pale rocky outcrops, four armored soldiers wield spears and swords to execute the martyr, who collapses to the ground, his halo still visible. The soldiers’ armor includes chainmail hauberks, conical helmets, and colorful gambesons. A lone statue on a plinth at the far right reiterates the cultic setting. Overlapping forms and a slight diagonal composition unify the indoor worship refusal and outdoor torture, while consistent color echoes and architectural framing maintain visual harmony. Secondary elements include the gilded frame, sculpted niches, and patterned floor. Symbolic components—the halo, idol, imperial regalia, and weapons—reinforce themes of faith versus worldly power. The decorative initial below references the same passage in Middle French, linking text and image through shared space and thematic content.

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This richly illuminated page, executed in a professional Parisian workshop circa 1400, exemplifies the late medieval fusion of narrative and devotional functions. The scene depicts the martyrdom of a saint under imperial authority, rendered in Middle French to serve a lay audience’s devotional practices. The use of ultramarine, vermilion, and burnished gold leaf reflects high-status materials linked to urban workshops catering to noble patrons. The micro-architectural framing with sculpted figures and acanthus scrolls in the initial connects to the International Gothic style, while the diptych-like composition—interior worship refusal on the left, exterior torture on the right—demonstrates narrative innovation within a single miniature. The halos, imperial regalia, and idol statue deploy symbolic iconography to underscore the conflict between true faith and enforced pagan observance, a theme resonant in post–Avignon papal propaganda. Technically, the layered pigment application with white highlights and subtle hatching shows advanced material mastery, while the precision of Gothic textura script aligns text and image in a coherent devotional layout. Comparatively, this leaf shares stylistic affinities with manuscripts from the Bedford Master’s circle, notably in its architectural framing and delicate dagger-point ornament. The page thus embodies a transitional moment where traditional hagiographic programs were enlivened by courtly aesthetic sensibilities, reinforcing both personal devotion and political messaging through sophisticated illumination.
